facts.text: This is an appeal under S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal under S. 35L of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944.

facts.text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold Control Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is directed against the order dated 15-4-1988 of the Customs Excise and Gold Control Appellate Tribunal, New Delhi.

facts.text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv of the Central Excise Tariff.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the manufacturer of Hacksaw blades and Bandsaw Blades falling under Tariff Item No. 51-A iv  of the Central Excise Tariff.

facts.text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985 furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of effective rates per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a classification list as per Rule 173B of the Central Excise Rules 1944 on 26-3-1985 in respect of their products furnishing the tariff rate of 15 ad valorem by mistake instead of furnishing the effective rates of duty as per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985.

facts.text: Aggregate value of the clearance in the preceding year i.e. 1984-85 did not exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The aggregate value of the clearance in the preceding year i.e. 1984-85 did number exceed Rs. 75 lakhs.

facts.text: In the case of first clearance up to an aggregate value not exceeding Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the effective rates of duty is nil and in the case of next clearance of Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the duty is 3.75 ad valorem.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of first clearance up to an aggregate value number exceeding Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the effective rates of duty is nil and in the case of next clearance of Rs. 7.5 lakhs, the duty is 3.75 ad valorem.

facts.text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, approved the tariff rate 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985 instead of the effective rates as the appellant did not claim the exemption due to ignorance.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, approved the tariff rate 15 ad valorem on 3-6-1985 instead of the above effective rates as the appellant did number claim the exemption as per Notification No. 85/85 CE dated 17-3-1985 due to ignorance.

facts.text: A revised classification list with the effective rates in respect of the products with retrospective effect from 26-3-1985 was filed on 31-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: A revised classification list with the effective rates in respect of the products with retrospective effect from 26-3-1985 was filed on 31-10-1985.

facts.text: The revised classification list was approved.

anchor.surface_text: The revised classification list was approved.

facts.text: The appellant claimed that they had paid excess Rs. 2,55,172.55 from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985 as excise duty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claimed that they had paid excess Rs. 2,55,172.55 from 1-4-1985 to 31-8-1985 as excise duty.

facts.text: Appellant made an application for refund under S. 11B on 30-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: They made an application for refund as per rule under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 on 30-10-1985.

facts.text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise by his order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned the refund claim only partly.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector of Central Excise by his order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned the refund claim only partly.

facts.text: Refund claim for period from 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 was rejected as time barred.

anchor.surface_text: For the period from 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985, the refund claim was rejected on the ground that the same was time barred.

facts.text: Assistant Collector held that under S. 11B relevant date for refund claim was date of payment of duty by adjustment in personal ledger account as goods removed.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector held that the refund claim for the period 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 was time barred for the reason that under S. 11B, the relevant date for preferring the claim for a case such as that of the appellant was the date of payment of duty and, according to him, the duty had been paid by adjustment in the personal ledger account as and when goods were removed.

facts.text: Plea of the appellant that mere detailing in personal ledger account should not be starting point for limitation and relevant date is date of RT-12 Returns assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the appellant is that mere detailing in the personal ledger account should number be taken as the starting point for limitation and the relevant date should be the date on which RT-12 Returns which are filed on a monthly basis are assessed.

facts.text: Order of the Assistant Collector was confirmed in appeal by the Collector of Central Excise Appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Assistant Collector was companyfirmed in the appeal by the Collector of Central Excise  Appeals .

facts.text: Further appeal to the Tribunal was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The further appeal to the Tribunal was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: Classification list filed by appellant for period 1-4-85 to 27-4-85 was not approved till 3-6-85.

anchor.surface_text: In this case, the classification list filed by the appellant for the period 1-4-85 to 27-4-85 was number approved till 3-6-85.

facts.text: RT-12 Return for the month of April, 1985 was filed on 8-5-1985 and assessed on 29-10-1985.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the RT-12 Return for the month of April, 1985 was filed on 8-5-1985 and the same was assessed on 29-10-1985.

facts.text: Clearance of goods by appellant between 1st April 1985 and 3rd June 1985 were provisional payments subject to final approval.

anchor.surface_text: In the present, case between 1st April, 1975 1985?  When the classification list was filed and 3rd June, 1985 when the list was approved, the assessee was clearing the goods by determining the duty himself and debiting the amount of duty in his personal ledger account. The amount of duty paid by him was obviously provisional andi subject to the result of the final approval by the officer companycerned.

facts.text: Refund application filed on 30th October 1985 is not time barred.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

facts.text: The appeal is allowed holding appellant entitled to full refund without limitation bar.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal. The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: They made an application for refund as per rule under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 on 30-10-1985. The Assistant Collector of Central Excise by his order dated 13-12-1985 sanctioned the refund claim only partly. For the period from 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985, the refund claim was rejected on the ground that the same was time barred. The Assistant Collector held that the refund claim for the period 1-4-1985 to 27-4-1985 was time barred for the reason that under S. 11B, the relevant date for preferring the claim for a case such as that of the appellant was the date of payment of duty and, according to him, the duty had been paid by adjustment in the personal ledger account as and when goods were removed. The plea of the appellant is that mere detailing in the personal ledger account should number be taken as the starting point for limitation and the relevant date should be the date on which RT-12 Returns which are filed on a monthly basis are assessed. The order of the Assistant Collector was companyfirmed in the appeal by the Collector of Central Excise  Appeals . The further appeal to the Tribunal was also unsuccessful. The question that arises for decision in the appeal is as to the starting point of limitation for filing an application under S. 11B of the Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944. S. 11B so far as it is material reads as under-- 11B. Claim for refund of duty.-- 1  Any person claiming refund of any duty of excise may make an application for refund of such duty to the Assistant Collector of Central Excise before the expiry of six months from the relevant date. Provided that the limitation of six months shall number apply where any duty has been paid under protest. Explanation -- For the purposes of this Section,--  A   B  relevant date means,--  a  to  d   e  in a case where duty of excise is paid provisionally under this Act or ihe rules made thereunder, the date of adjustment of duty after the final assessment thereof  f  in any other case, the date of payment of duty.

concepts.interpretation: Refund claim must be filed within 6 months from relevant date unless paid under protest; relevant date depends on whether duty paid provisionally or otherwise

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e such as that of the appellant was the date of payment of duty and, according to him, the duty had been paid by adjustment in the personal ledger acc

I73B, 173D, and where applicable 173C, 173CC, he shall himself determine his liability for  he duty due on the excisable goods intended to be removed and shall number, except as otherwise expressly provided, remove such goods unless he has paid  he duty as determined.

anchor.surface_text: Under R. 173G, every assessee shall keep an account current with the Collector. This rule lays down the procedure which is to be followed by the assessee for payment of duty. According to sub-r.  3  of R. 173G, within five days after the close of each month every assessee shall file with the proper officer a monthly return in the prescribed form showing the quantity of the excisable goods manufactured, duty paid on such quantity and other particulars.

concepts.interpretation: Account current/personal ledger debit is effective payment but provisional if pre-approval; monthly RT-12 return leads to assessment under R.173I

anchor.surface_text: Under R. 173C, the assessee shall file with the proper officer a price list in prescribed form. Prior approval of the price list by the proper officer is necessary in the specified cases. Here also sub-rule  5  of R. 173C provides-- Subject to the provisions of R. 173CC, an assessee specified in sub-rule.  2  shall number clear any goods from a factory, warehouse or other approved place of storage unless the price list has been approved by the proper officer.

concepts.interpretation: Price list approval required; provisional under R.9B if delay

anchor.surface_text: Under R. 173CC, assessee may remove goods in certain cases pending approval by the proper officer of the classification of price list.

concepts.interpretation: Allows removal pending list approval subject to conditions

anchor.surface_text: To understand this argument, it is necessary to refer to Self-removal procedure under which the appellant cleared the goods. Chapter VII-A of the Rules relates to removal of excise goods on determination of duty by producers, manufacturers or private warehouse licensees.

holdings.text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is not a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

anchor.surface_text: Where an assessee maintains a personal ledger account, duty is paid by way of debit therein and goes to reduce the amount of deposit paid by the assessee. It is number a mere adjustment entry it is effective payment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Debit in personal ledger reduces assessee's deposit balance, constituting actual payment of duty under clause (f) where applicable.

holdings.text: In the self-removal procedure under Chapter VII-A of the Central Excise Rules, clearances of goods pending approval of the classification list under Rule 173B constitute provisional payment of duty akin to Rule 9B procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In the present, case between 1st April, 1975 1985? When the classification list was filed and 3rd June, 1985 when the list was approved, the assessee was clearing the goods by determining the duty himself and debiting the amount of duty in his personal ledger account. The amount of duty paid by him was obviously provisional andi subject to the result of the final approval by the officer companycerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending approval, assessee self-determines and debits duty provisionally subject to final approval and RT-12 assessment under Rules 173B, 173C, 173CC, 173F, 173G, 173I, equivalent to provisional assessment under R.9B without bond due to account current.

holdings.text: Clause (e) of Explanation B to Section 11B applies where duty is paid provisionally under the self-removal procedure.

anchor.surface_text: In such a situation cl. e of para B of the Explanation under S. 11B will be attracted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clearances between filing and approval of classification list are provisional, attracting clause (e) rather than clause (f).

holdings.text: The relevant date under clause (e) of Explanation B to S.11B is the date of adjustment of duty after final assessment of RT-12 return.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the RT-12 Return for the month of April, 1985 was filed on 8-5-1985 and the same was assessed on 29-10-1985. It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final assessment under R.173I of monthly RT-12 return finalizes provisional duty, triggering limitation from adjustment date.

holdings.text: The refund application filed on 30th October 1985 is not time barred under S.11B.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, only from the date of this assessment that time bar in S. 11B will operate. In the present case the refund application had been filed on the 30th of October, 1985. It cannot, therefore, be said to be time barred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Filed within 6 months of RT-12 assessment on 29-10-1985.

holdings.text: The appellant is entitled to full refund of excess duty paid, and the appeal is allowed.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, allow the appeal. The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No limitation bar applies; reverses Tribunal's finding on time bar.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal has therefore to be allowed holding the appellant is entitled to the full amount and there is numberbar of limitation as found by the Tribunal. We, therefore, allow the appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; appellant entitled to full refund of Rs. 2,55,172.55 as the refund claim is not time-barred under S. 11B
directions: Appellant entitled to the full amount
